lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
React allows us to change what we display based on the code and the user's input.

Rendering JSX based on certain conditions is called conditional rendering.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use an if/else statement to introduce JavaScript logic into JSX and control what is rendered based on a condition.

Check if the number variable equals 42 to render the appropriate element.

Make sure to pick if, followed by number === 42, and finally else.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use embedded expressions to embed the JSX into other JSX codes.

This is useful if we want to control smaller dynamic elements while keeping the greater JSX structure intact.

Make sure to pick {, followed by response, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Conditional statements become more relevant when working with properties.

Check if the passed property number is 42.

Make sure to pick props followed by props and then ., number.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we don't hardcode a value we test against but pass it as a property, we make the component reusable and useful for other components.

Make sure to pick number followed by = and then {, 42, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render different messages based on the weather condition using conditional rendering.

Make sure to pick if followed by condition and then ===, "sunny".

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be the output of the following code?

Welcome backPlease log inError rendering JSXNo output

Welcome back.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a different greeting based on the time of day using a conditional expression.

Make sure to pick props followed by . and then time, ===, "morning".

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which will be displayed when using the following JSX?

Please sign upWelcome to the siteNo outputRendering error

Please sign up.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code by checking if the passed property age is greater or equal to 18.

Make sure to type props.age.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Determine the result of this React app.

It's hotIt's chillyNo outputError rendering

It's hot.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a component that displays a message depending on the type of day: weekday or weekend.

Make sure to pick let followed by dayMessage and then ;, dayMessage, dayMessage, dayMessage.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
When working with properties, we can go further with conditional rendering to make the component as flexible as possible.

Let's check out how we can decide whether to render something or avoid it.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we don't want to show an element in a certain condition, we can set it to null.

Make sure to pick element followed by = and then null, ;.

The embedded expression will always render the content that's referenced by the element variable.

However, when this variable holds the value null, there is nothing to display.

Make sure to pick element followed by element and then element, element.

lessons.title: 1 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the showSecret variable to true to render the secret message.

Make sure to pick true.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
This concept becomes more relevant when working with state variables.

If we transform showSecret into a state variable, we can toggle whether to render it with the click of a button.

Make sure to pick useState followed by false and then toggleSecret, toggleSecret.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a simple React component that conditionally renders a message based on a prop value.

Make sure to pick if followed by props and then .isOpen, else.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens if a React component returns null in its render method?

Nothing will be displayedA blank space is rendered"null" is displayed on the screenAn error will be thrown

Nothing will be displayed.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Build a button component that conditionally renders an emoji based on a prop.

Make sure to pick SmileButton followed by props and then ., showSmile, {, smile, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
What prop value will render the text You've won a prize! ðŸŽ‰ in the following component?

truefalsenullundefined

Make sure to pick true.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component that shows a hint if a given prop is true.

Make sure to pick if followed by props and then ., showHint, else.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, how can you conditionally render a component element?

Using an if statementUsing a switch statementUsing an alert methodUsing a prompt method

Using an if statement.
